statement.tex: %text If the radius of a sphere is measured as 9 cm with an error of 0.03 cm, then find the approximate error in calculating its surface area. %

step.context: %text If S be the surface area of the sphere and R its radius, then which of the following is the error in calculating the surface area? %
step.reason:
%text \[ \frac{dS}{dR} \] is the \underline\text{rate of change} of the surface area with respect to the radius - but \underline{not} \underline\text{the actual change}.
That would be $\Delta S$, which is given by
% \qquad \Delta S = \frac{dS}{dR}\cdot \Delta R

step.context: %text Given the expression for $\Delta S$, how much will the error be when $R = 9cm\pm 0.03 cm$? %
step.reason: \begin{align} \frac{dS}{dR} &= \frac{d}{dR}(4\pi\cdot R^2) = 8\pi R \\ \text{and }\Delta R &= 0.03\text{ cm} \\ \therefore [\Delta S]_{R=9cm} &= \frac{dS}{dR}\cdot\Delta R \\ &= 8\pi R\cdot \Delta R \\ &= 8\pi\cdot (9cm)\cdot (0.03 cm) \\ &= 2.16\pi\text{ cm}^2 \end{align}
